repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem:
- Despite [nvim-lspconfig](https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig) claims to be a "data-only" plugin, in fact it still provides some user-facing commands because they haven't been upstreamed to Nvim.

Solution:
- Upstream some user commands from `nvim-lspconfig` as `:lsp restart`, `:lsp start`, `:lsp stop`.

TODO:
- [x] fix slow `:lsp start` completion
- [ ] [not support multiple-clients in args](https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig/pull/3896#issuecomment-2959581087)
- [ ] not support inline comments (add flag `NOTRLCOM`). Not sure if TRLBAR should be removed too
- [ ] Add tests (but where?)
<!--
  Thank you for contributing to Neovim!
  If this is your first time, check out https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-requests-prs
  for our PR guidelines.
-->

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,105 @@
+local lsp = vim.lsp
+
+local M = {}
+
+--- @param filter? vim.lsp.get_clients.Filter
+--- @return string[]
+local function get_client_names(filter)
+  return vim
+    .iter(lsp.get_clients(filter))
+    :map(function(client)
+      return client.name
+    end)
+    :filter(function(name)
+      return not not vim.lsp.config[name]
+    end)
+    :totable()
+end
+
+---@param clients string[]
+local function ex_lsp_stop(clients)
+  -- Default to disabling all servers on current buffer
+  if #clients == 0 then
+    clients = get_client_names { bufnr = vim.api.nvim_get_current_buf() }
+  end
+
+  for _, name in ipairs(clients) do
+    if vim.lsp.config[name] == nil then
+      vim.notify(("Invalid server name '%s'"):format(name))

comment_data.body:
Restart should imho also support the case where the client was started via `lsp.start` instead of going through lsp.config/lsp.enable, and it also needs to make sure the server is fully stopped before it is started again. Otherwise for servers which use the fs for state management it might end up corrupting it.

E.g. my current custom `:LspRestart`:

```lua
  api.nvim_create_user_command(
    "LspRestart",
    function(kwargs)
      local name = kwargs.fargs[1]
      for _, client in ipairs(lsp.get_clients({ name = name })) do
        local bufs = lsp.get_buffers_by_client_id(client.id)
        client:stop()
        vim.wait(30000, function()
          return lsp.get_client_by_id(client.id) == nil
        end)
        local client_id = lsp.start(client.config, { attach = false })
        if client_id then
          for _, buf in ipairs(bufs) do
            lsp.buf_attach_client(buf, client_id)
          end
        end
      end
    end,
    {
      nargs = "?",
      complete = function()
        return vim.tbl_map(function(c) return c.name end, lsp.get_clients())
      end
    }
  )
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,105 @@
+local lsp = vim.lsp
+
+local M = {}
+
+--- @param filter? vim.lsp.get_clients.Filter
+--- @return string[]
+local function get_client_names(filter)
+  return vim
+    .iter(lsp.get_clients(filter))
+    :map(function(client)
+      return client.name
+    end)
+    :filter(function(name)
+      return not not vim.lsp.config[name]
+    end)
+    :totable()
+end
+
+---@param clients string[]
+local function ex_lsp_stop(clients)
+  -- Default to disabling all servers on current buffer
+  if #clients == 0 then
+    clients = get_client_names { bufnr = vim.api.nvim_get_current_buf() }
+  end
+
+  for _, name in ipairs(clients) do
+    if vim.lsp.config[name] == nil then
+      vim.notify(("Invalid server name '%s'"):format(name))
+    else
+      vim.lsp.enable(name, false)
+    end
+  end
+end
+
+---@param clients string[]
+local function ex_lsp_restart(clients)
+  -- Default to restarting all active servers
+  if #clients == 0 then
+    clients = get_client_names()
+  end
+
+  for _, name in ipairs(clients) do
+    if vim.lsp.config[name] == nil then
+      vim.notify(("Invalid server name '%s'"):format(name))
+    else
+      vim.lsp.enable(name, false)
+    end
+  end
+
+  local timer = assert(vim.uv.new_timer())
+  timer:start(500, 0, function()
+    for _, name in ipairs(clients) do
+      vim.schedule_wrap(function(x)
+        vim.lsp.enable(x)
+      end)(name)
+    end
+  end)
+end

comment_data.body:
> (Also raises a bit the question if :lsp stop is "stop server" or "stop and disable server")

Since I just copied the logic from `nvim-lspconfig`, its description is the same as in there ["Disable and stop the given client"](https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig/blob/4d3b3bb8815fbe37bcaf3dbdb12a22382bc11ebe/plugin/lspconfig.lua#L178).

Maybe `:lsp disable` is a better name?

+local lsp = vim.lsp
+
+local M = {}
+
+--- @param filter? vim.lsp.get_clients.Filter
+--- @return string[]
+local function get_client_names(filter)
+  return vim
+    .iter(lsp.get_clients(filter))
+    :map(function(client)
+      return client.name
+    end)
+    :filter(function(name)
+      return not not vim.lsp.config[name]
+    end)
+    :totable()
+end
+
+---@param clients string[]
+local function ex_lsp_stop(clients)
+  -- Default to disabling all servers on current buffer
+  if #clients == 0 then
+    clients = get_client_names { bufnr = vim.api.nvim_get_current_buf() }
+  end
+
+  for _, name in ipairs(clients) do
+    if vim.lsp.config[name] == nil then
+      vim.notify(("Invalid server name '%s'"):format(name))
+    else
+      vim.lsp.enable(name, false)
+    end
+  end
+end
+
+---@param clients string[]
+local function ex_lsp_restart(clients)
+  -- Default to restarting all active servers
+  if #clients == 0 then
+    clients = get_client_names()
+  end
+
+  for _, name in ipairs(clients) do
+    if vim.lsp.config[name] == nil then
+      vim.notify(("Invalid server name '%s'"):format(name))
+    else
+      vim.lsp.enable(name, false)
+    end
+  end
+
+  local timer = assert(vim.uv.new_timer())
+  timer:start(500, 0, function()
+    for _, name in ipairs(clients) do
+      vim.schedule_wrap(function(x)
+        vim.lsp.enable(x)
+      end)(name)
+    end
+  end)
+end
+
+local actions = {
+  restart = ex_lsp_restart,
+  stop = ex_lsp_stop,
+}
+
+local available_subcmds = vim.tbl_keys(actions)
+
+--- Use for `:lsp {subcmd} {clients}` command
+---@param args string
+M._ex_lsp = function(args)
+  local fargs = vim.api.nvim_parse_cmd('lsp ' .. args, {}).args
+  if not fargs then
+    return
+  end
+  local subcmd = fargs[1]
+  if not vim.list_contains(available_subcmds, subcmd) then
+    vim.notify(("Invalid subcommand '%s'"):format(subcmd), vim.log.levels.ERROR)
+    return
+  end
+
+  local clients = {}
+  for i, client in ipairs(fargs) do
+    if i > 1 then
+      table.insert(clients, client)
+    end
+  end

comment_data.body:
I think I will use `table.concat` or even just `fargs[2]`, because it seems like Justin doesn't want to support many client args

(I would prefer the latter `fargs[2]` (lsp name with space should be escaped) since it doesn't require changing how `nvim_parse_cmd()` should parse args)

comment_data.body: A little thing about the invalid server name. I'm using the official copilot plugin, and if I run `LspStop` (that comes from `nvim-lspconfig`), I get: I don't know if it's because that plugin does weird stuff, because the name contains spaces, or another reason.

comment_data.body:
@brianhuster thanks for the link, but I didn't explain myself correctly.
What I wanted to say is that some LSPs (now I know it's those started with `vim.lsp.start` won't be stopped by nvim-lspconfig's commands, so maybe the upstreamed version in neovim could be modified to handle those as well.

comment_data.body: The point of this PR is to upstream commands from `nvim-lspconfig`. So I think `nvim-lspconfig` should change first. I can't find a comment that explain why `nvim-lspconfig` change the behavior of those commands like that, so I prefer not to go too far myself.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
    Object res = NLUA_EXEC_STATIC("return require'vim._core.ex_cmd'.lsp_complete(...)", args,
```
`vim._core.ex_cmd` does not exist. Are you suggesting moving `lsp/_cmd.lua` to `_core/ex_cmd.lua`?
yes. Lua builtin modules should only live in `_core/`.

Is there a reason this `[32] = ` bit is here? It doesn't exist for any other commands, and all tests still pass when it's removed. I'm going to remove this, but I just want to verify this is okay with someone who understands the C part of the code better than I do.

comment_data.body: This isn't new to this PR, but we tend to use language servers and language clients interchangeably in our docs which might be confusing. Unfortunately `nvim-lspconfig` isn't any better at this ([this snippet](https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig/blob/b3a31fd3b6702de9c71c27212ffacf0f54cc3b46/doc/lspconfig.txt#L77-L98) basically treats client and server as synonyms), but I think that we should use `client` to better align with the Lua API of `get_client_by_id`, `get_clients`, etc.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -124,6 +124,22 @@ To remove or override BUFFER-LOCAL defaults, define a |LspAttach| handler: >lua
       end,
     })
 <
+
+COMMANDS                                                    *:lsp*
+
+:lsp restart {names}                                      *:lsp-restart*
+    Restarts the given language servers. If no names are given, all active

comment_data.body:
Nit:
```suggestion
    for name in pairs(vim.lsp.config._configs) do
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,142 @@
+local lsp = vim.lsp
+
+local M = {}
+
+--- @param filter? vim.lsp.get_clients.Filter
+--- @return string[]
+local function get_client_names(filter)
+  return vim
+    .iter(lsp.get_clients(filter))
+    :map(function(client)
+      return client.name
+    end)
+    :filter(function(name)
+      return vim.lsp.config[name] ~= nil
+    end)
+    :totable()
+end
+
+---@return string[]
+local function get_config_names()
+  local config_names = vim
+    .iter(vim.api.nvim_get_runtime_file('lsp/*.lua', true))
+    ---@param path string
+    :map(function(path)
+      local file_name = path:match('[^/]*.lua$')
+      return file_name:sub(0, #file_name - 4)
+    end)
+    :totable()
+
+  ---@diagnostic disable-next-line: invisible
+  vim.list_extend(config_names, vim.tbl_keys(vim.lsp.config._configs))
+  return vim.list.unique(config_names)
+end
+
+local complete_args = {
+  start = get_config_names,
+  stop = get_client_names,
+  restart = get_client_names,
+}
+
+local function ex_lsp_start(servers)
+  -- Default to enabling all servers matching the filetype of the current buffer.
+  -- This assumes that they've been explicitly configured through `vim.lsp.config`,
+  -- otherwise they won't be present in the private `vim.lsp.config._configs` table.
+  if #servers == 0 then
+    local filetype = vim.bo.filetype
+    ---@diagnostic disable-next-line: invisible
+    for name, _ in pairs(vim.lsp.config._configs) do

~~Oops! Completely missed this one! I renamed all the rest but this one slipped through the cracks.~~

Nevermind. I didn't realize which PR this review was on. This problem is obsolete, and has been fixed in the new version. If you could review #36825 that would be great.

comment_regular_data.body:
@justinmk Maybe the command shouldn't support trailing bar and comments as well?

And for "only accepting one client name", should I use `table.concat(fargs, 2)` (any strings after restart/stop is a client name) or `fargs[2]` (client name with space should be escaped)? I prefer the latter because it allies with how `nvim_parse_cmd()` parse the command.

> Maybe the command shouldn't support trailing bar and comments as well?

Is that because `|"` might be needed for some args?
 
> And for "only accepting one client name"

That constraint was to avoid over-engineering these things and keep them simple. 

> client name with space should be escaped)?

well the only purpose of commands is to be ergonomic, for interactive use. Though I guess completion will usually do the escaping.

> Is that because |" might be needed for some args?

Coz I am sure comment is useless in interactive usage, but just not sure about bar

> That constraint was to avoid over-engineering these things and keep them simple.

The command already have to support multiple-clients in case no client-args are given, so making it support multi-client args doesn't make it any more complicated IMO. But I don't have strong opinion on either way

apologies if this is not the right place to comment, as i found no linked issue.

as a regular user, i'm really excited about this feature!

yet, i have a few concerns about the current impl:
* what if an user does not use `lsp.{config,enable}()` facility but bare `lsp.start()`?
* what if lsp spawns many lsp-clients with the same lsp.config.x? i believe it's possible by setting lsp.config.x.{root_dir,reuse}. if so, name for lsp start/stop {name} can be ambiguous.

and i'd like to suggest some features based on my workflow:
* list all lsp-clients globally or buffer-locally
* list lsp-clients being idle, those are not attached to any buffer
* expire 'idle' lsp-clients, say being idle for 5 minutes

> list all lsp-clients globally or buffer-locally

That is a job for `:checkhealth vim.lsp` (which does need some improvements to better show the "current buffer" state).

Besides rebasing, this PR may be able to be simplified a bit since the auto-shutdown enhancements were added (nvim-lspconfig is leveraging those I think) https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/36455 .


Otherwise shouldn't over-think this and let's just get something merged that we can iterate on. Any "breaking" changes to Ex commands have a lower bar because they are primarily for interactive, not programmatic, use.
I would also be in favor of an `:lsp stop` which stops a client without disabling it, although that addition can come in a later PR.

>  Add tests (but where?)

`./test/functional/ex_cmds/lsp_spec.lua` or `./test/functional/plugin/lsp_spec.lua`. Doesn't need to be deep, just 1-2 tests that exercise the codepath.

Once the merge conflicts are resolved and tests are added, it would be great if we could get this PR merged, and then iterate improvements. I'd love to help work on this ([rename to enable/disable](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/35078#discussion_r2233173360), [better restart which works with `vim.lsp.start()`](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/35078#discussion_r2233125898), [possibly adding other subcommands](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/35078#issuecomment-3586888113), etc.), but as it stands unmerged I can't.
@superatomic do you want to take this over? Just keep the existing commit with @brianhuster as author, and create a new PR with a new commit(s) on top of it
I would be happy to! I'll start on that soon.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability

title: feat(ex): add :lsp command
